NOT URBAN AIRSHIP?!

So, a bit about Django - we use Django for our main API. We used it originally because that's what we knew and it was easy to get up and running. But it's been one part of the stack that we haven't really needed to scale at all. It mostly stays out of the way and doesn't bother us. There are definitely shitty parts, and a few queries that we've had to rewrite, but considering all of our scaling issues, it's impressive how little we've had to touch our front end.
"It mostly stays out of the way and doesn't bother us." - That's like the best endorsement any technology can get ever.

hah... yeah. It'll get rewritten in java one day. @cscotta will come in and be like, "oh, yeah, I'm getting three billion requests per second with this Tomcat thing that does everything the Django site does.."
fucker.
Wait, shit, what's the etiquette here, do I start a new group/discussion/topic?
conversations naturally drift
cool. I'll just consider this a drunken/open thread for now then.
Some people were showing me Play and the bits they were showing off were just awesome.
I mean, my "verbosity" meter is probably really fucked up due to our exposure to Java... but the stuff that Play does seems epic.
So what bits were particularly awesome?
....that's totally not on my screen. OMG CONVORE BUG

I liked their global translation/template text variable thing, I liked their routing and how functions are set up and mapped to urls or, basically, whatever. The templating was kind of lame, definitely clearly based off of Rails.
I'll take that as "none" :P
Wait, what's none?
"So what bits were particularly awesome?"
Seriously?
I wonder what went wrong there.
http://cl.ly/2h3g1z1R060s3Y2h2844 (proof! A refresh fixed it)
Also it's java, and you don't need to scale Java, so.... you know.. that's cool.
@mtrichardson My feel of Play is that it is Rails circa 2006 for Java. Big deal for Java land, but anti-climactic for everyone else.
The coolest thing about Play is that it totally violates every expectation that Java developers have about programming
no dependency injection, no getters and setters, auto-recompilation when you hit save without an IDE
we got pretty excited about it at the Guardian, where lots of our stuff is in Java and the Java devs were getting jealous of Django being used for all the rapid-prototyping stuff
@simonw The crazy auto-migration in dev mode is insane.
